title: Will killing al-Baghdadi boost Trump in 2020?
text:
By the end of April 2011, Barack Obama’s approval rating had fallen to the lowest level of his presidency: 43 percent, according to Gallup, with 48 percent disapproving. Unemployment was at 9 percent, and 70 percent of Americans were saying the country was on the wrong track. Then, on May 2, Obama announced that after a decade-long manhunt, Navy SEALS had killed al-Qaida leader and 9/11 mastermind Osama bin Laden during a raid in Pakistan. Obama’s approval rating immediately shot up above 50 percent for the first time in 14

months. His disapproval rating fell to 40 percent, its lowest level since the first year of his

presidency.

Unemployment was at 9 percent, and 70 percent of Americans were saying the country was on the wrong track. Then, on May 2, Obama announced that after a decade-long manhunt, Navy SEALS had killed al-Qaida leader and 9/11 mastermind Osama bin Laden during a raid in Pakistan. Obama’s approval rating immediately shot up above 50 percent for the first time in 14
months. His disapproval rating fell to 40 percent, its lowest level since the first year of his
presidency.
